paragraph.htmltext: Note that the tests are depending on the application in which the cells are used.

Preproduction testing should be extensive to confirm the design and production process. These testing procedures are not all-inclusive. Tests are designed to confirm that the cells have the desired performance characteristics and are robust enough to resist abuse conditions should they arise.

New cell designs, including critical changes shall pass specified tests identified by the manufacturer/supplier before qualification as production cells.

Specification of test can be found in relevant cell testing standards. The manufacturer/supplier should be know the standards and utilize one or more of these standards as part of their testing process.

Performance tests describe the test procedures to obtain the essential characteristics of lithium-ion cells, power density, energy density, storage life and cycle life. Standards (IEC 62660 â€“ 1, ... ) describe the following procedures:
• Charge performance: To determine if a battery meets the performance requirements when used with a specific charger model.

• Power and calculation of the power density and regenerative power density
  • Energy and calculation of the energy density
  • Energy efficiency test

• Extended charging at standard temperature: determine the ability of a battery to withstand extended charging time at standard temperature.
  • Effect of discharge rate on capacity delivery
  • Effect of temperature during discharge rate on capacity delivery
  • Effect of temperature during charge rate on capacity delivery
  • Effective internal resistance
  • Internal impedance
  • Charge efficiency
  • Overdischarge performance
To obtain data about the reliability of the cell, standards describe, depending on the application, the following test procedures:
• Vibration test: test performed to characterize cell responses to vibration assumed in normal use.
• Mechanical shock : test performed to characterize cell responses to mechanical shocks assumed in normal use.
• Terminal endurance test: determine the ability of the battery to withstand repeated insertion and withdrawal operations to its connection mechanism and continue to deliver the required capacity
• High temperature endurance: performed to characterize cell responses to high-temperature environment.
• Temperature cycling: performed to characterize thermal durability of cell by exposing at low and high temperature environment alternately to cause expansion and contraction of cell components.
• Continuous charging at constant voltage (for portable applications)

Abuse tests

During the design and development of a cell, abuse tests should be executed to determine the response of the cell to conditions or events which are beyond their normal operating range. The test procedures are described in standards according to which the test can be performed.

The following abuse tests are described in standards:
• Crush test : test performed to characterize cell responses to external load forces that may cause deformation
• External short circuit : performed to characterize cell responses to external short circuit.
• Overcharge : performed to characterize cell responses to overcharge
• Forced discharge : performed to characterize cell responses to over discharge
